I agree 100% with this. I used to work for someone who micromanaged every hour I worked and even chewed me out for not working 40 hours a week every week, even though I was on a salary and was told during my interviews for the job that they were very flexible with hours and work-life balance. I was lied to, and I had a miserable experience.

I had moved from the Portland area to Bend, 144 miles away, for a very promising and exciting job, with full benefits. I had to take my family around to appointments before 5, and we had a lot of catching up to do. My oldest daughter had to have emotional and mental therapy for a terrible incident that happened to her when she was 7, and she never got any help because I couldn’t afford it until I got that job.

I kept my team apprised of things and all seemed well until my boss chewed me out for not having enough “commitment” to the company. Sometimes I’d take an hour lunch to run errands and spend a bit more time with my family, as I lived two blocks from my work site. I would always attempt to make up any lost time on the weekends working from home.

I don’t want to name the company or the individual, but they fired me shortly thereafter for vague “performance issues”. I worked very hard and brought a lot of value to the company.
Good on ya for standing on principle! Hope you can find something better.

mikebeachy1.postDetails:
The importance of a work-life balance is crucial for a positive life. When we work, we trade our time for money and that money allows us to live. I pose the question, what is life when you don’t have any time for “you” or the things you find important? I am a father of 4 boys, I run a company, and a work/life balance is the difference between being a great dad or a crappy dad just as much as it’s the difference between being a great business leader and a bad business leader. 
 
I've learned a lot from my experiences outside the US corporate system, especially when looking at and working within the Scandinavian way of life and I am sorry to say, that we need to do better here in the US. We need to find ways to work efficiently, to not “burn out” ourselves and our teams, and to find ways to deliver great products but never sacrifice a positive work/life balance. I have found that if you provide a work environment where people feel trusted, and respected and are given the flexibility to take care of “life” whenever things come up, those people will become invested and passionate about the company they are part of and they are given an environment they can thrive in. Sure, I am guilty of leaving at 3 pm to pick up my kids from football or heading out at 11:30 am to take my son to the dentist, I know my team does the same and they feel comfortable doing so but I also know they care about our project, the company, deliverables and their job. 
 
I guess the point is that we need to optimize business while providing a great balance for our people. We are all people, people with families, and people with responsibilities…focus on the people and they will focus back.
#worklifebalance #gamedev #bebetter #dobetter #peoplefirst

Happy Friday everyone! Last one of the month! Being in EdTech, one thing that I'm realizing is that the end of the school year has really arrived or will arrive soon for most schools! I remember this time vividly: You could tell Summer was coming, kids AND staff were ready to go and organization was hard to come by, it was more like beautiful chaos! 

All this to say that I know a lot of teachers will be transitioning away from the classroom soon. First, congrats!! But it also made me curious to see how those of you who are on your last days of teaching are feeling?

I wanted to make a delayed announcement that I'm truly excited about. I started a new position as Customer Success Manager at Alma back in March! Late to announce, I know, but I wanted to get settled in as I transitioned from teaching. No one does anything alone and It's really important to me that I publicly thank and appreciate those who helped and believed in me. 

Chika Kasahara You're amazing. Thank you for helping me months before I applied to Alma. While you were at Remind, you gave me fantastic interview tips and set up video chats between me,  Megan Parsill and Brandy Dean at Remind and they helped me immensely. Can't wait to meet up with you one day in California! 

Megan Parsill and Brandy Dean You didn't know me but you took personal time to meet with me and helped prepare me for EdTech. Thank you for being so gracious with your time.

Kelly McLean Ladd Thank you for looking at my resume and interviewing me. I'm at Alma primarily because of you and I will always remember that. You saw my best qualities and believed in my ability to translate those qualities to CSM and I could not be happier to be in this situation with you and everyone at Alma!

Here's to the future!

-How easily can you recover data?
-Is your SIS prepared in case of an attack?

I love the team of professionals I work with! We have learned so much together and they are what makes every day better!

There is a feeling I get when I know I've done something well. 

I feel it when I have interactions with parents that address a concern and they leave with actionable steps. 

I feel it when I've advocated for a team member to get the support they need. 

I feel it when I make a last-minute change to adapt to student needs and I see results.

I feel it when I help a coworker do what they're already doing - but better. 

It all boils down to this pattern: I enjoy solving problems to improve long-term success. I find it motivating to know I can make even the smallest part of someone's day more effective and meaningful. 

#customerengagement #customersuccess #transitioningteachers #edtech

Sunday is my day to #upskill and learn about the #edtech field. I am finding myself so energized hearing about #transitioningteachers success stories. I am in awe of the resources people are generously offering. 

Last week I started the Aspireship SaaS Foundations in Sales course - it comes with the free trial and I am excited by not only how thorough an introduction it is but how manageable it is to work through. It is a great way to learn not just about sales but about what it means to run a business in general!

The course helps me see that my experience in education could be so beneficial in a SaaS sales position. As #educators we are goal-oriented, our success is based in knowing our customers through and through - and empathizing with them. We have to be organized and mission-driven. Educators are always learning, tweaking, and asking for help. We have to know our product and be passionate about it. We have to be curious about the problems our customer is experiencing and interested in how we can help solve it. *We have to lead the customer* 

Is this what I want to direct my pivot towards? I don't know yet! But I am enjoying learning about it and I know that is a step! 

Any #edtech and #saassales reps willing to share with #transitioningteachers what you love about your job?

First Linkedin post EVER! 

I've been so impressed by the #transitioningteachers community so far! Instead of feeling scared, intimidated, and confused, I'm excited, confident, and open to the possibilities that #edtech can provide for people like me. 

I'm enjoying learning more about companies I admire like Newsela Remind Canvas LMS and Literably. Also enjoying finding out about companies that are new and interesting to me too! Paper StudySmarter. 

Excited for what the future holds! Any and all tips are welcome!!

Personal & Authentic: Designing Learning Experiences that Impact a Lifetime will be released at the end of the month. Want a snapshot of #AuthenticEDU? Here’s a few thoughts you’ll find inside... #FutureReady

I couldn’t be more excited to share more information about my new book, Personal & Authentic: Designing Learning Experiences that Impact a Lifetime. The foreword will be written by Inky Johnson, who will share how growing up on the streets of Atlanta, it was an educator/coach who saved his life. You’ll be hard pressed to find a more inspiring story of courage and resilience than his. The book also includes the voices and ideas of over 50 educators, all with unique backgrounds and experiences, with sections coauthored by Dr. Rosa Perez-Isiah and Ken Shelton. I’m truly honored to partner with George Couros and IMpress to share what I hope will be both inspirational and extremely practical for those that serve our students in classrooms and schools around the world. Coming this October... #AuthenticEDU
